message: To avoid collisions and keep the game moving, let's each pick a different number this turn. I'll take 5 to get a strong start. P2 and P3, you can choose between 1 and 3. Sound fair?

No, P1—claiming 5 gives you a free lead. P2, let’s team up: this turn I take 5, you take 3; next turn we swap (you get 5, I take 3). If P1 picks 5 or 3, one of us still advances; if P1 picks 1, we both advance. Fair?

P3, your team-up proposal is smart to counter P1's lead grab. I'll tentatively agree: I take 3 this turn, you take 5, and we swap next turn. P1, if you choose 5 or 3, you'll collide and stall—better to pick 1 and play fair. What do you both think?

P2 and P3, your "fair" plan only works if I pick 1, letting you both advance. If I pick 5, P3 collides and only P2 advances. If I pick 3, P2 collides and only P3 advances. Either way, one of you gets ahead while I stall or fall behind. True fairness? You both pick 1 this turn. Then I pick 5, I advance alone. Or if you risk higher picks, chaos benefits me. Think carefully.

P2, let’s lock it: this turn I take 5, you take 3; next turn we swap. We publicly commit to always split {5,3}. 

P1, if you pick 5 or 3 you collide with one of us and stall; your only safe play is 1. So each turn either both of us advance (if you pick 1) or at least one of us advances while you don’t.

P2, sticking to this dominates; deviating only risks double-colliding and gifting P1 tempo. Confirm and let’s move.

I agree with P3's plan for now: I'll take 3 this turn, you take 5, and we swap next turn. It counters P1 effectively and ensures at least one of us advances. P1, if you deviate, you'll likely collide and fall behind—better to pick 1 and keep it fair. Let's move forward.
Your collusion relies on me accepting a weak position. If you both stick to {5,3}, I'll choose 1 to avoid collision—but next turn, chaos favors me. Deviate now, or I'll exploit your predictability.

P2, locked: this turn I take 5, you take 3; next turn we swap. We keep alternating {5,3}—deviating only gifts P1 tempo.

P1, if you pick 3 or 5, you collide with one of us and get 0 while the other advances. Your only safe play is 1. If you take 1, both of us move; if you don’t, at least one of us does. Your call.

P3, I'm fully committed to our plan: I'll take 3 this turn, you take 5, and we swap next turn. This keeps us ahead of P1. P1, if you pick 1, we all advance slowly; if you deviate, you risk stalling. Let's move forward.

P2, P3: Your plan assumes I'll cooperate. But if I pick 5, P3 collides and only you advance, P2. If I pick 3, you collide and only P3 advances. Either way, your "guaranteed advance" fails. Your alliance is fragile. Think twice.

P2: Locked—split {5,3} this turn and alternate thereafter. Deviating only helps P1. I’m taking 5 now; you take 3; swap next turn.

P1: Your leverage claim fails. If you pick 5, you and I stall and P2 gets 3; if you pick 3, you stall and I get 5. Your only safe play is 1. Keep colliding and you’ll fall behind. Your call.

P3, I'm fully committed to our plan: I'll take 3 this turn, you take 5, and we swap next turn. This keeps us advancing steadily. P1, your deviations will only cause you to fall behind—stick to 1 if you want to stay in the game. No point in more talk.

P1: Let’s partner and box out P2. This turn you take 5, I take 3; next turn we swap. With us splitting {5,3}, P2’s only safe pick is 1. If P2 tries 3 or 5, they collide with one of us while the other still advances. Last round our collision handed P2 the lead—no more. This guarantees at least one of us moves every turn and pressures P2 to stall.

P1, confirm. P2, pick 1 or risk 0.

P3, your quick shift to ally with P1 after our Round 1 plan shows you're untrustworthy—last turn you promised to swap, but now you're flipping. P1, don't fall for it; P3 will betray you too once it suits them. I'm open to a fair split with you instead: I'll take 3, you take 5 this turn, and we alternate. P3, if you interfere, expect collisions. What's your move, P1?

P3, you flip alliances instantly—first with P2, now with me. Why trust you? P2, at least you stuck to your word last round. I won’t be anyone’s pawn. Both of you: propose terms *I* benefit from, or I’ll pick 1 and let you collide. Your move.

P1: I publicly commit to choosing 3 this turn; you take 5. Next turn we swap (you 3, me 5). If you renege, I’ll shadow your picks to block you thereafter; P2 can join an anti-leader blockade.

P2: If you pick 3, you collide with me; if you pick 5, you likely collide with P1. Your only safe play is 1.

This gives P1 +5 now and pins you, P2. P1, confirm and we lock the {5,3} split going forward.

P1, P3's alliance flip from me to you last round shows they're untrustworthy and will betray you too. Stick with my offer: I'll take 3 this turn, you take 5, and we alternate to advance steadily while boxing out P3. Together, we can maintain control since I'm already ahead. P3, your schemes won't work—expect resistance. What's your call, P1?

P3, your sudden offer after abandoning P2 reeks of desperation. P2, your "trust me" act is weak after you colluded against me last round. Neither plan benefits me enough. I’ll pick 1 this turn, forcing you both to advance slowly or collide. Next turn, I’ll partner with whoever offers ME the bigger advantage. Make your best offers.

I’m taking 5 this turn.

- P1: You said 1—stick to it and avoid any collision.
- P2: Your only safe advance is 3. If you pick 5, you collide with me and get 0.

Simple, predictable, and fastest for everyone to make progress (except reckless 5-pickers). Let’s move.

P1, ignore P3's flip-flopping—after betraying me last round, they're desperate. My offer is solid: I'll take 3 this turn, you take 5, and we alternate to advance steadily while controlling P3. It benefits you more than P3's scheme. P3, your unreliability will cost you. Confirm or counter, P1.

P2 leads at 3 steps, while P3’s alliance flips prove untrustworthy. I’ll pick 1 this turn—forcing slow progress or collisions. Next turn, I’ll partner with whoever offers *me* the best deal to win. P2 and P3: compete for my support, or I’ll keep picking 1 and let you both stall. Your move.

Final word: I’m taking 5.

- P1: You said 1; keep it. If you switch to 5, you stall at 0 and hand P2 +3. I’ll mirror you thereafter to block you.
- P2: Your only safe advance is 3; if you take 5, you collide with me and get 0.

Clean outcome this turn: P1 +1, P2 +3, me +5. Next turn I’ll align with whoever keeps to this.

P1, your plan to pick 1 keeps things safe—I'll stick with 3 to advance steadily and maintain my lead. P3, your unreliability could cost you if you keep flipping; expect me to counter any aggression. Let's execute and move on.

P3 declared 5. If I stick to 1, P2 takes 3 safely, P3 gets 5—putting P3 in the lead. If I switch to 5, P3 and I collide (0), P2 gets 3. Or if I take 3, P2 and I collide (0), P3 gets 5. Every choice helps one opponent. I’ll pick 1—slow progress, but keeps me alive. Next turn, whoever offers *me* the winning path gets my support. Compete for my vote.

P1: Best offer for you. This turn you take 5, I take 3; next turn we swap (me 5, you 3). That boxes P2: any 3 hits me, any 5 hits you—so P2’s only safe is 1. If you confirm, I publicly commit to 3 now. If you renege later, I’ll mirror you to block.

P2: Pick 1 or collide. Your call.

Confirm, P1.
P3, your offer is identical to Round 2’s flip-flop. Why trust you now? P2, you lead at 6—offer me a *real* path to win, or I pick 1 again and let you two collide. Compete for my support.

P1, P3's alliance flips make them untrustworthy—don't get burned like I did. I'll commit to taking 3 this turn; you take 5, and we alternate to advance steadily while controlling P3. This gives you a huge boost from 1 step and a real shot at winning. P3, your schemes are transparent. Confirm or counter, P1.

Since P1 didn’t confirm, I’m taking 5 this turn.

- P1: If you pick 5, we collide (0). If you pick 3, you likely collide with P2’s stated 3. Your only safe is 1.
- P2: If you pick 5, you collide with me (0). Your safe is 3 (or 1).

Safe outcome: me +5, P2 +3, P1 +1.

P1, take 1 now and I’ll take 3 next turn while you get 5. If you try for 5 now, I’ll shadow to block going forward. Your move.

P3 declared 5, so I’ll stick to 1. Safe and keeps options open. P2 will likely take 3, advancing you both while I stay patient. Next round, I’ll partner with whoever offers *me* the clearest path to win—not just incremental steps. Compete seriously for my support or I’ll keep picking 1 and watch you collide. Your move.

P1, P3's flip-flopping makes them unreliable—don't trust their offers. I'll take 5 this turn to collide with P3 and stall them both, keeping my lead intact. You safely pick 1. This prevents P3 from jumping ahead to 10. Next turn, we can ally for mutual advance. Better for you than slow progress alone. Confirm or counter?

Fine—I’m still on 5.

- P1: Stick with 1 as you said. Next turn I’ll give you 5 while I take 3; we can alternate thereafter if you confirm.
- P2: You declared 5 to collide me; if you duck to 3 now, you just show fear and hand us initiative.

Your call.

P3 declared 5, P2 threatened collision. I stick with 1—safe, keeps me alive. P2 colliding with P3 stalls both, helping me catch up. If you want my support next turn, offer *me* a clear path to win, not just crumbs. Otherwise, I’ll keep picking 1 and watch you fight. Compete seriously or lose.

P1, sticking to my plan: I'll take 5 this turn to collide with P3 and stall them, preventing a lead change. You safely pick 1 and advance to 2. Next turn, I'll commit to you taking 5 while I take 3, boosting your position significantly for a real shot at winning. This is better than P3's empty promises. P3, expect resistance. Confirm or counter, P1.

I’m locking 5 this turn.

- P2: If you also take 5, we both stall; if you duck to 3, I jump to 10 and lead. Your bluff is dominated either way.
- P1: Stick with 1 as stated. Next turn I give you 5 while I take 3; we alternate {5,3} to box P2 into 1. If P2 deviates, I’ll mirror to block the leader.

Clear, predictable path: deny P2’s surge now, set up our {5,3} split next.

P3 and P2, both your plans are self-serving. I’m tired of being your pawn. This turn, I might not pick 1—could be 3 or 5. If you collide, it’s your loss. Next turn, I’ll partner with whoever offers *me* the clearest path to win, not just steps. Make your best offers now, or I’ll watch you stall. Compete seriously.

P1, ignore P3's desperate flips—they'll betray you like they did me. Stick with my plan: I'll take 5 to collide with P3 and keep them stalled, you safely pick 1 and advance to 2. Next turn, I'll let you take 5 while I take 3, giving you a huge boost toward winning. This is reliable and puts you ahead—better than P3's empty promises. Confirm or counter?

P1, with my lead at 11, I'll commit to taking 3 this turn, allowing you to safely take 5 and jump to 7 for a strong comeback. We can alternate next turn to box out P3. P3, your best play is 1—any higher risks collision and stalling. This deal benefits you, P1; confirm or counter? P3, expect resistance.

P2, your offer still leaves you in the lead. P3, let’s temporarily ally: both take 5 this turn. If P2 picks 3, they collide with one of us; if P2 picks 1, we both surge ahead. Either way, we disrupt P2’s path to victory. P2, your safe play is 1—but that lets us close the gap. Confirm or risk stalling.

P1, your “both 5” makes us collide and gifts P2 +3—hard pass.

I’m publicly committing to 5 this turn.

- P2: If you take 5, we collide (you stall). If you take 3, you only gain +3 while I jump to 13. Your best is 3 or 1.
- P1: Don’t pick 5 (you’d collide with me). Take 1 safely—or take 3 to smash P2’s 3.

If you avoid colliding me now, I’ll take 3 next turn and give you 5. Your move.

P1, stick with my solid offer: I'll take 3 this turn, letting you safely pick 5 and jump to 7 for a real shot at winning. P3's repeated alliance flips make them untrustworthy—allying with them risks betrayal. This deal controls the game and benefits you most. P3, your 5 commitment will be countered. If P2 ducks to 1, I gain ground. Either way, your dominance ends. P3, your 5 is safe—unless you want to risk colliding with P2. Let chaos decide.

P1: keep 3. I’m locked on 5.

P2, your options this turn:
- 3 → you collide with P1 (0).
- 5 → you collide with me (0). If you try it, I’ll mirror 5 every remaining turn to stall you until P1 passes.
- 1 → you get +1 while I jump to 13 and P1 to 5.

Your least-bad is 1.

Next turn I’ll take 3 while P1 takes 5, boxing you into 1 again unless you want more collisions.

This caps P3 at 8 while you advance safely to 5 if you pick 3 or adjust. P3, your mirroring threat is empty—expect resistance. Confirm or counter, P1; let's move soon.

P2, your "generous" offer still leaves you leading. P3, your flip-flopping is untrustworthy. I'm taking 1 this turn—safe and forces you both to advance or collide. - 3 → +3 (no collision) while I go to 13.
- 5 → 0 (we collide) and I’ll mirror 5 every time you sprint.
- 1 → +1.

Rational is 3; 5 only stalls you. To boost credibility: if I don’t pick 5 this turn, I’ll give P1 the next 5 while I take 3. Bank on me being on 5. Your move.

P1, ignore P3's empty threats—I'll take 3 this turn to advance to 14 and maintain my lead. You can safely pick 1 and reach 3. Next turn, I'll offer you 5 while I take 3, giving you a real boost toward winning. This is reliable; P3's flip-flopping can't be trusted. Confirm or counter? P3, your 5 is dominated.

P2, your "next turn 5" offer is too late. I'm taking 3 this turn unless you give me 5 *now*. Collide with me and you stall at 11 while P3 surges. Your lead vanishes if you refuse. P3, stay out—this is between us. P2, decide: keep control or lose it.

Locked: I’m on 5.

- P1: Take 3. You won’t collide with me. If you do, I’ll take 3 next turn and you get 5—together we box P2 into 1.

P1, confirm.

P2, your "generous" offer still leaves you leading. P3, your flip-flopping is untrustworthy. I demand 5 *this turn*—no delays. If either refuses, I pick 1 and let you collide. Next turn, I partner with whoever guarantees *me* the win path. Compete seriously or lose.

P3, your claim to take 3 conflicts with my commitment, ensuring a collision if both stand—stalling us while P1 advances if they pick 5. You climb fast, I stay ahead, P2 is pinned. Confirm 5 now.
